title: We really need to increase base resistances
body:
Ever wonder why Wukong / Quinn back in the day weren't so strong.. but now they literally 3 shot you?

Mundo cleavers doing an insane amount of damage? No MR glyphs.

> [{quoted}](name=Nhifu,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6rVsWl8a,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-07-13T15:47:11.072+0000)

Buffing resist actually makes tanks worse. See the thing is resistance have diminishing returns. So if you give everyone a free Cloth armor, ADC/mage ect types end up getting like 5% damage reduction, Bruiser/fighter types get like 2.5% more and tanks end up getting like 1% more.

Resistance has no diminishing returns.
Don't think that less an increase in % means diminishing returns.
Take it to the extreme: 1%? nothing right? well add 1% to 99% and you will be completely immune to physical damage.
Every 1 armor adds 1% effective health

If this isn't enough to convince you then read [another post](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/O4Lc80Pm-defense-is-mathematically-inferior-to-damage?comment=000c000100000000) I made or read the [wiki](https://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Armor).

But you are somewhat right, buffing the base values of all champions tankyness (health & res) lowers the contribution of resistances or health of other sources.
Again take it to the extreme, if base resistances and health were very influential and items almost not, then buying defensive items isn't really worth it as you only increase your survivability a little. On the flip side are all other champions almost equal tanky and picking a meat shield simply is not worth it as you don't bring anything unique (everybody is as tanky as you).

Keep in mind that only increasing base resistances increases the value of health, which work together to create tankyness. Adding global resists has to be done careful so not the lower the viability of resistance items too much.

> [{quoted}](name=Rouwhorst,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6rVsWl8a,comment-id=0000000000010000,timestamp=2018-07-14T07:25:16.757+0000)
>
> Resistance has no diminishing returns.
> Don't thing that less an increase in % means diminishing returns.

Yes, it does it's. You get less DR% per armor you get. For example getting 50 armor and going 10-60 armor takes you from 9% to 38% damage reduction or 29% damage reduction from 50 armor. Now if you have 210 armor and you gain 50 armor going to 260, you go from 68% to 72% damage reduction or 4% from 50 armor.

29% for 50 armor
4% for 50 armor
That's called diminishing returns bud please learn how the game works before calling me out.

The calculation for the damage multiplier from armor (above 0 armor) is: 100/(100+armor)
So 10 armor has a damage multiplier of 100/110 = ~0.909

Let's calculate the physical damage needed to bring down a 1000 health unit.
If the unit has 10 armor he would only take 0.909 (90.9%) of the damage.
The damage needed would be: 1000/~0.909 = 1100
60 armor: 1600 health; 210 armor: 3100 health; 260 armor: 3600 health.
As you can see the required damage increase from both applications of +50 armor is equal.

The percentages might look like they have diminishing returns but they don't.
The effect of damage reduction becomes much greater the higher percentage it is.
An increase in 25 percentage points reduction is not that big of a deal if you go from 0% to 25%, but an increase from 75% to 100% is.
0% to 25% means you can take 1/3th (33%) more damage (as 1/0.75 = 1.333).
75% means 3 times more damage (1/0.25 = 4) and 100% means immunity (1/0 = )

31 seconds vs 36 seconds =  1.16 longer to kill for having 50 armor

No really armor has diminishing returns
